review I heard reviews on this book on how hard and difficult it is with the plot and characters. When I read this book I didn't have much difficult with the I heard reviews on this book on how hard and difficult it is with the plot and characters. When I read this book I didn't have much difficult with the plot or characters (although they are hard to pronounce and some character's names are very similar to other characters or switching from first name to last name and such, which can be quite confusing). Fyodor gave us a every descriptive account of the story, with interesting conversations, plot twists (which kept you guessing whats going to happen next), and so much more. Although I didn't understand parts of this book I was thoroughly engaged with what C+P offered the reader, I'd read this book over sometime in the future to get a better understanding of the book. ...more

review I'd give this book a 4.5, but opted to give it 5 stars instead of 4. Whether you are an Extrovert or an Introvert, You'll find that if you are an Intro I'd give this book a 4.5, but opted to give it 5 stars instead of 4. Whether you are an Extrovert or an Introvert, You'll find that if you are an Introvert that there is nothing wrong with you its just many (mostly Extroverts?) shun or think they are 'dumb or stupid' (which is quite the contrary) when in fact Introverts are incredible people and we should learn to understand them and give them their room to explore their inner mind. For Extroverts they'll (hopefully) learn that about 1/3 of the people you know are Introverts and are not quite as out going, loud persons you think they should be. Yes Introverts can become 'quasi-Extroverted' at times, but they are still an Introvert at heart. About a few months ago I learned that I was a Introvert, I kinda thought something was wrong about me, but reading this book and doing my own research on Introversion I found comfort in what I read online and in Quiet that Introverts are amazing people. ...more

review For years I've seen this book laying on my parents bookshelf and always thinking 'I'd never read that' or 'I wouldn't learn anything from that old boo For years I've seen this book laying on my parents bookshelf and always thinking 'I'd never read that' or 'I wouldn't learn anything from that old book'. I decided a few months ago to give this book a try, I'm so glad I did. I have learned some new tricks to use when talking to someone and wanting to achieve something without being harsh or mean, but saying it in a nice way like praising some thing they do good and ending with a suggestion. I think there were some points in this book that I have already done with my conversations with others, but it was a nice refresher to read those parts. I know I'll have to read parts of this book over now and then to get a refresher on some of the ways mentioned in this book. ...more

review I'd like to thank Goodreads for having the First Reads program so that many of the average readers can read a book before it hits the stores. A Blaze I'd like to thank Goodreads for having the First Reads program so that many of the average readers can read a book before it hits the stores. A Blaze of Glory: A Novel of the Battle of Shiloh is the first book I ever won from Goodreads' First Reads program and I hope to win future books and give a review for the book. This book is the first book I've ever read from Jeff Shaara. The story takes place with the events before Shiloh and eventually leads up to the battle of Shiloh. Portrayed by both North & South's Generals like: Grant, Johnston and Sherman you get to see both sides of the story with thoughts about their family, troops, death, difficulties and other things that might be going through their mind. Jeff puts in detail of sounds and din's like: slushing sound of mud, thunder, musket fire and other small details to make the story come alive. I'll have to say there were a few parts here and there that were quite humorous to not feel like the book is all about war and death. It was a pleasure to be one of the First Readers to read A Blaze of Glory: A Novel of the Battle of Shiloh. ...more

review This book is a necessary read for all readers/lovers of pirate/swashbuckling/treasure hunting books (and the alike). Robert Louis Stevenson's Treasure This book is a necessary read for all readers/lovers of pirate/swashbuckling/treasure hunting books (and the alike). Robert Louis Stevenson's Treasure Island was possibly one the first books to revolutionize this genre, although I have heard many of the items like treasure maps, schooners, one-legged seamen, parrots were made up by Stevenson and have become 'popular misconceptions' about pirates. I remember watching the movie 'Treasure Planet' back some years ago and I looked it up some information about it and found it was based on a book and told my self 'that book is old as hell I won't ever read that old book'. Well I guess I out did my self and gave in to read it to see what all the hype was about this book and pirates. I'll have to say the story line was quite interesting with many interesting characters. I did find some parts of the book to be a little confusing, hence the 4 stars. My favorite characters would have to be Ben Gunn and Long John Silver. I'll definitely read this book again in the future. ...more

review I'm not sure what to think of this book. Except for: 'best of books and the worst of books' I'd have to say it is somewhere near the middle for me. I I'm not sure what to think of this book. Except for: 'best of books and the worst of books' I'd have to say it is somewhere near the middle for me. I did like the writing style, yet I found the subject matter quite confusing at points which throws me off when I don't understand some important details. I did have some notes found in the back which helped some, but some weren't too helpful. I think somewhere around reading 1/3 of this book I kinda lost interest in this book and I can see why. I should stayed with the former and quitted this book early on, I thought it might have gotten better, but I thought wrongly. Hopefully some of Dickens' other works are in better shape for me to enjoy his writing. ...more

review 'Wait and Hope' are some lovely closing words to leave the reader with. I didn't know what I was going to get my self through when I bought this book 'Wait and Hope' are some lovely closing words to leave the reader with. I didn't know what I was going to get my self through when I bought this book yet I don't regret it either. I can only second Robert Lewis Stevenson's review: 'A piece of perfect storytelling.' because it is dam near well close to a perfect storytelling, although there were parts that seemed to drag on about history and such the rest of the book made up for it. Whilst reading this book I came across a multitude of words that I knew about but didn't know their meaning too well and some new words, that improved my vocabulary. Going on with the vocabulary I'd say that this translation of Count of Monte Cristo is a excellent version, although there might be many difficult words for some people to keep track and I'd recommend having a dictionary with you and pen and paper to keep track of the words you have come across already. As a closing word I'd like to say that I'm not sure if one influenced the other or if it might be a coincidence that some parts of this book felt like parts were from Les Misérables, yet it felt like a completely new book. ...more

review Initially when looking at reviews online and such I found many mixed reviews that some liked it and others loved this book. At first I was quite hesit Initially when looking at reviews online and such I found many mixed reviews that some liked it and others loved this book. At first I was quite hesitant to read this book because I might not like the book or find Rand's work unimportant for today's world. I found it to be just the opposite, I actually loved this book, there might have been some small parts that I didn't understand but for the most part I enjoyed this book. I read this in one setting, which was quite nice. I think there are groups or societies and maybe people(?) that, in a way, are depicted in Anthem, that if you try to challenge their values they may attack you in some form or another. In other words you can take the 'we', that is consistent through out the book, and place some group/organization/society/etc. as the 'we'. It may not apply to every thing you substitute as the 'we' but I think you get the idea. I got quite a bit out of reading this short novel. It even made me think for some time after reading about the ideas and themes and how to apply them to today's world. I hope Rand's work in Fountainhead and Atlas Shrugged is as good or even better than Anthem because I plan on reading them some time soon. ...more

review Its been a while since I've had a book that made me laugh and this book accomplishes that and much more. The Gospel of the Flying Spaghetti Monster is Its been a while since I've had a book that made me laugh and this book accomplishes that and much more. The Gospel of the Flying Spaghetti Monster is mainly a religion made up (just like the Invisible Pink Unicorn) by Atheists to demonstrate to religious people what they believe in is just as valid and ridiculous as a Flying Spaghetti Monster (but they don't get the picture we Atheists are trying to paint for them). Although if there is a God I'd believe in I'd believe in the Noodly Appendage of FSM than I would any other god. I mean come on who wouldn't want a heaven that has a stripper factory and a beer volcano and a hell thats has strippers that have STD's and the beer is mild or having Friday to be a holiday to relax and try to get some sun. RAmen! ...more
